g.text: There is increasing recognition of rising adaptation challenges and associated costs within and across
Developed countries. Undoubtedly many developed countries are spending more on wide range of
adaptation issues both as preventive measures and building resilience (greening infrastructure, climate
proofing major projects and managing climate related risks)
against the impacts of climate change
. Developed countries climate change adaptation spending
areas such as federal insurance programmes, federal, state and local property and infrastructure,
The analysis of financing gaps in climate action, which is used to measure implementation action and
annot be carried out as a pure demand
challenge, in isolation from the analysis of barriers to deploy funds (e.g.
and to take investment initiatives. These barriers are friction that prevents socially optimal investments
. They are at the root of the
paradox” of a deficit of infrastructure investments despite a real return between 4% and 8%
(Bhattacharya et al., 2016), of the low share of carbon saving potentials tapped by dedicated policies
, and, more generally of a demand
inance lower than the volume of economically viable projects
A few exercises tried and assess the consequences of the perpetuation of these drivers on t
of the financing gap. They suggest, comparing the evolution of the infrastructure investment trends
(beyond energy) by comparison with what they should be in an optimal scenario, a cumulative deficit
gap is of the same order of magnitude than the incremental infrastructure investmen
C target, 2.4 % of the world GDP on average, (
) calculated by exercises assuming no pre
for Europe and the 2% of the
for the G20 which do not encompass many developing countries of which economic take
ay fossil fuels dependent. For low and middle income economies,
suggest to increase the infrastructure investments by 2.5 to 6 percentage points of the GDP to cover
both the reduction of the structural investment gap and the specific additional costs for bridging it with
low carbon and climate resilient option
These assessments indicate the challenge at stake but do not
exist at very disaggregated sectoral and regional levels for sectors other than energy.
The below quantitative analysis does not differentiate between financing gaps driven by barriers within
or outside the financial sector given that the IAM models as well as most other studies used do not
incorporate actual risk ranges depending on policy strength and coherence and institutional capacity,
investment costs and barriers within the financial sector that are discourage private sector funding. They
), high perceived risks for mitigation relevant
technologies and/or regions (information gap through incomplete/
balancing for regional mismatches between current capital and needs distribution, e.g.
), and perceived high opportunity and transaction costs (results from limited visibility of future
nd policy interventions; SME financing tickets and the missing middle, e.g.
). In addition, barriers outside the financial sector will have to be addressed to close future
